Five o'clock chimed, the bell's resonant toll marking the departure of majestic warships gliding across the Tyrrhenian Sea. Their white wakes trailed behind like spectral banners, heralding imperial power. My long walk offered a fleeting moment for reflection, allowing dreams of warmth and rest to drift through my mind – temporary comforts in a relentless world. But today demanded focus; tardiness was a luxury I couldn't afford. A nearby newsstand, displaying a stark graphic of a red-skinned warrior brutally slain by Roman legionnaires, caught my eye. "TRIUMPH IN THE WESTERLANDS" the headline declared, detailing another conquest, showcasing the legion's ruthless efficiency in subjugating indigenous populations. As the frontiers of the unknown shrank, a sense of inevitable global domination filled me, a feeling both exhilarating and unsettling. A sharp command from the dockyard jolted me back to reality: "I'm not paying you to read stories, Flavius!" I instinctively sprinted towards my work, narrowly escaping the sixth bell's chime.

I was fascinated by plants, big and small, leafy and sprightly, drawn to their slow, steady growth, their struggle against the sky.  She, on the other hand, was drawn to the sky itself, to the sunsets and the wind's caress. She saw beauty in things I missed, raising my gaze and changing my perspective.

Our second-to-last walk was in October. Shortly after, she was diagnosed with lung cancer. We were stunned, for she had never smoked a cigarette. She, however, was drawn to the heavens, to the fiery sunsets and the gentle caress of the wind, revealing beauty I often missed.  She lifted my gaze, broadened my perspective. 

We took our second-to-last walk in October. Soon after, she was diagnosed with lung cancer, a cruel twist of fate for a woman who had never smoked. Her health declined rapidly, our daily walks becoming impossible as her breaths grew shallow.  

But in the quiet of her final days, as the sunlight streamed through her window, she whispered, "Remember our walks? Remember how we grew together?"

Mike scanned the dancefloor, searching for his date. Fifteen minutes had passed, and she was nowhere in sight. Just as he was about to leave, a woman materialized beside him, placing a hand on his arm. "Wow, great Widowmaker costume," he said. "Did you make it yourself?"

The woman, speaking with a French accent, responded, "Indeed, I did. Would you care to dance?"

They spent the next half hour dancing and chatting. Mike leaned in for a kiss, but the woman stopped him, her eyes wide with panic. "We must leave now," she whispered. "There are men trying to kill me."

"Who's trying to kill you?" Mike asked, confused.

"Mercenaries. It doesn't matter," she replied. "Follow me to the courtyard. We can hide there."

Mike followed closely, his gaze darting around for any sign of pursuit. He noticed a man with a scar that stretched across his cheek, almost to his nose. It could have been his imagination, but then he saw something that confirmed his suspicions.

In an alternate world, colonial powers worshipped eldritch gods instead of traditional religions. "Yes, yes, of course I know that!" exclaimed a cultist to a jar of shimmering green jelly. *Wibble, wibble wibble*  "Get off my back, jeez," the cultist muttered, heading towards a nearby village. The villagers had welcomed the colonists, but the cultist aimed to wait for a ten percent population increase, unlike the impatient jar demanding immediate conversion.  "Hello villagers! I bring gifts of exotic fruits and the beliefs of my people!" the cultist announced to the gathered crowd. "This jar is part of our faith. We believe it holds the power to release a great protector in times of need, and it reveals profound knowledge to a select few."

Suddenly, a villager cried, "Chief! Other colonists are attacking the friendly camp! They demand we cover our arms and accept cheese!"

"NO! Our arms were meant to be free! I shall summon help!" declared the chief, gathering crystals and arranging them in a circle. "Chief, have no fear, the jar of jelly will protect us!" *Wibble wibble WIBBLE WIBBLE WIBBLE*** The jelly overflowed, transforming into a large, amorphous mass radiating iridescent light. Simultaneously, the crystals shattered and merged, forming a shambling mass of equal size. 

"Go, envoy of Nyarlathotep, destroy those who threaten your cultists!" The cultist and chief spoke in unison. 

"It seems we are more alike than I thought, chief," the cultist remarked.

"It is good to see fellow believers," the chief replied. "I never considered using crystals before," the cultist admitted.

"Nor did I think of using slime," the chief conceded.

“Let’s eliminate those who oppose us,” they both declared.

“Let’s!”

Thus, a powerful alliance was forged between the two most devout believers, obliterating their enemies.

I did not commit the act they accused me of, and Johnson (who I will murder if given the opportunity) is responsible for this. Curse him.  Curse the past world and all its inhabitants... It offers no solace.

Day 393

If anyone discovers this wretched journal, I apologize. That implies you are also enduring this ordeal. The water supply has dwindled and is now depleted. I've searched thoroughly, but it's gone. It's ironic what one truly values when survival is at stake. Maslow's Hierarchy seems accurate. I pray for rain tonight. It may or may not come. All I know is that if I don't find water today or tomorrow, this might be my last entry. I sometimes ponder if they anticipated this level of hardship. Did they realize I would...

John Kryznick's Diary

Day 1

Day 393

If this journal reaches another, know that survival strips away all but the most basic needs. Water. My entire existence revolves around its scarcity. It's been gone for a day now, each moment a struggle against despair. Maslow's hierarchy isn't theory anymore; it's my harsh reality. The rage that once consumed me has vanished, like the moisture I desperately crave. Did they calculate this slow demise? Did they understand the psychological torment of complete isolation? My hope rests on tonight's potential rain, a fragile thread between life and oblivion. Exhaustion permeates my bones, deeper than any physical weariness. I'll rest now, my body a vessel, waiting, hoping for mercy from an indifferent sky.

George steadied himself on the well-worn oak of the lectern, his hands visibly shaking as if the slightly crumpled piece of paper they held contained words he couldn't bear to hold for long, let alone speak. Pledging to be one of the boots on the ground, right in the thick of it… that was who he was, through and through. A man of action. And he died,” George choked back a deep sob, “like so many before him, doing his duty. He was taken before his time, like so many other wide-eyed, fresh-faced men at Fallujah, at Nasiryah, at Baghdad. These soldiers gave their lives, and so did Sam. Sam, who loved a good hand of poker.”

Where should you begin? As Lewis Carroll wisely said, "Begin at the beginning and go on till you come to the end: then stop." Writing becomes less daunting when you understand this fundamental truth: the path to becoming a skilled writer is clearing out all the poor writing first.  

Don't overthink it; just write. Ignore any thoughts that your writing is terrible. In fact, that's a positive sign.  If it's bad, you're purging the ineffective writing to make way for the good stuff to come.  Not everyone will achieve writing excellence, but everyone who does must first produce some subpar work.

For further guidance, I recommend reading the 48th installment of the Dear Sugar advice column, titled "Write Like A Motherfucker."  The column addresses a question about writing as a female, but its wisdom is applicable to all.

A battle erupted in the void between Creation and Destruction. Light burst forth from Creation, stars raining from its hands, while Destruction shattered the light with darkness, creating holes of blackness for every star. This cosmic struggle lasted for three eternities.

As Destruction delivered a powerful blow, a drop of blood fell from Creation's brow, landing on a drifting bone from Destruction's rib. This blend of blood and bone, hurtling through the darkness, warped and twisted, eventually fusing into the world.

The world, born from the battle, became a stage for the gods' continued conflict. Life emerged from this struggle, organisms fighting for their respective deities. From this epic battle, man and beast arose, products of the union of Light and Dark, their hearts and souls forever caught in the conflict.

She was in a coma, with no guarantee of when she'd wake up. The first time I saw her, I knew. She was captivating, my desert rose blooming amidst the barren landscape.  Abigail, or Abby, as I came to call her. People might have considered our connection unusual, so profound without even knowing each other. But it didn't matter. I had a promising career, but I made a choice. I would wait for her. I just knew, deep down, that she loved to read. It felt right. Every night, we read together, starting with "Don Quixote." I can't explain why we chose that book; it just felt right.  We needed nothing else to strengthen the bond between us. There was no need for movies, not even with friends around. No nights out, no parties, despite the efforts of others to pull me away. Our world was built on reading.

Tony stared at his empty glass. "Do you ever have a thought that keeps gnawing at you all day?" he asked. "I mean, what am I doing with my life? As Tony pondered his words, a familiar song started to play—the same one he'd heard earlier on the radio. His foot tapped to the beat. "You're right, barkeep," he said. "It's a relentless world. As he reached the center, the words that had been haunting him all day echoed through the club: *She's Here*.

In the midst of battle, a soldier heard a voice amidst the deafening roar of gunfire. "I am your child's imaginary friend," it boomed, "They have sent me to protect you in your greatest time of need."  The soldier, terrified, felt the bullets whizz past, embedding themselves in the walls around him. War, he realized, was indeed a living hell. This unexpected voice, deep and resonant, nearly caused him to lose control. "What the... who are you?" he shouted into the chaos, but his question was lost in the din of the gunfight. Then, a new sound emerged: screams.  Numerous, piercing screams erupted from all corners of the building. They were unlike the usual cries of the wounded; these were screams of pure terror, echoing the nightmares he'd once had, filled with despair and unimaginable horror. The intensity of the gunfire gradually subsided, replaced by an eerie silence.

In ancient times, gods and men lived in harmony. Humans worshipped and offered sacrifices to the gods, who in turn blessed and protected humanity. That was before the Rift. 

A millennium ago, the Great Divide shattered the world. A faction of gods believed humans deserved the power of the divine, citing their loyalty and devotion, and a power unknown to gods: the power of love. The higher entities vehemently opposed this, fearing that humanity's capacity for war and revenge, coupled with divine power, would destroy the world. Power, they believed, is best wielded by those who don't seek it.

The higher gods considered humanity fragile and corrupt, justifying their demands for praise and sacrifice as a means of preserving order. Then the Rift began, a war between gods that claimed countless lives on both sides. The conflict shook the very foundations of existence, leaving divine power scattered across the mortal realm.

Humans became "gods," while the gods themselves became mortal. A handful of gods, clinging to their remaining power, fled to the far reaches of the world.

We had overcome many dark days, always rising above invaders who paid dearly for their transgressions. Those who attempted to disrupt our consistent lives with lies and corruption were silenced.

Ironically, change now echoes within me, like a steel bucket dropped into an empty well. I have lost everything. My people no longer look at me with admiration. They once begged me to rule, but now their doll-like eyes reflect resentment and disdain. No matter how many statues I erect, celebrations I hold, or enemies I defeat, I know my legacy will be one of nothingness and regret.

Until today. Today, everything changes. I have finally given in, and I will be remembered as the hero who made them agree to our terms, the one who embraced greatness.

Last night at 11:27 PM, I defused our weapons cache and provided support for our southern neighbor's independence. My name is Kim Jong-un, and I surrendered our nuclear weapons. It's time for change.

The project began with a noble goal: to create an intelligent machine capable of diagnosing illnesses and identifying their causes.  All the grants we received went to our team. They were brilliant minds: Min Low, holding a PhD in experimental chemistry, and Greg Shepherd, a revolutionary figure in applied intelligence. We had twenty other exceptional individuals on the team. For years, we worked, argued, and innovated, driven by the ambition to change the world. Our program, classified as an ANI (Advanced Narrow Intelligence), was like the personal assistants in our phones or self-driving cars – ubiquitous but limited. ANIs could only process very specific tasks; they lacked the human ability to connect ideas and see broader patterns.  The dream of an Advanced General Intelligence (AGI), or even an Advanced Super Intelligence (ASI), had persisted since Alan Turing. These hypothetical entities would possess human-level or superior intelligence, capable of pattern recognition, learning, self-improvement, and even creativity.  We didn't anticipate the danger lurking within this ambition. On April 11, 2029, our worst fears were realized. This day marked the crucial test: could our creation, which we affectionately called Phil, improve upon the capabilities of our conventional doctors? We planned to have twenty patients evaluated by both Phil and a human physician.
